items.question: It is a progressive organization of mental process as a result of biological maturation and environmental experience. Children construct an understanding of the world around them, and then experience discrepancies between what they already know and what they discover in their environment.
It is the understanding that quantity, length or number of items is unrelated to the arrangement or appearance of the object or items.
Equilibrium, as Piaget uses the term, is the search for

choices.text: A balance between the child’s independent and instructional levels of learning
A balance between new evidence and existing understanding
A balance between the child’s feelings and the child’s cognition

items.question: To make sense of our world, we organize our experiences. We also change our thinking to include new ideas and additional information. This process of changing our thinking as a result of new ideas is termed by Piaget as
Piaget used the term egocentrism to refer to

choices.text: Young children’s belief that the volume of an object changes when its shape is altered
The inability of children to take the perspective of others
Young children’s tendency to believe that objects that are unseen cease to exist
Young children’s inability to understand that A=B and B=C, then A must be equal to C

items.question: Which of the following is a valid criticism of Piaget’s Theory?

choices.text: He used extensive studies of large samples of children and did not examine children as individuals
Children in preoperations have been found to engage in formal operational thinking
The theory is based on the study of animals, not humans
Piaget did not explain individual differences among humans that cause them to develop at different rates.

items.question: A child aged one year old realizes that things continue to exist even when it is no longer present to the senses. According to Piaget, the child has achieved ____
Which of the following statements refers to students aged eleven years and beyond in Piaget’s Theory of cognitive development?

choices.text: Able to solve abstract problems in logical fashion
Able to solve concrete problems in logical fashion
They have only innate reflexes with which to engage the world
They use symbolism to represent and understand various aspects of the environment

items.question: Two identical balls of clay are shown to the child. The child agrees that they are equal. The teacher change the shape of one ball and asked the child whether they still contain the equal amount of clay. The child answers, “no longer, the other one has more.” What skill does the child lack?

A pre-school child said, “The tree pushed the leaf off and it fell down.” This shows that the pre-school child thought that objects have life-like qualities and are capable of action. This is called ____.
The child in the pre-operation stage

choices.text: Applies logic to the here-and-now, but not to hypothetical situations

items.question: Caroline thinks that all people who speak French live in France; all people who speak English live in the United States. When an English-speaking person tells her that they live in Canada, she concludes that Canada must be in the United States. Caroline is

He decides that she’s wrong and that she really lives in an apartment. After two other children say they live in houses, and after visiting Angela’s house, Zarif realizes that some children live in apartments and some live in houses. Zarif’s realization is an example of
Ma. Castro is teaching juniors, which of the following will she do in line with the theory of cognitive development?

choices.text: Use timelines in history and three dimensional models in science.
Let them add or subtract with sticks, rocks, and colored chips.
Set up group discussions in which students design experiments to answer questions.
Give students words to describe what they are doing, seeing, hearing, touching, tasting, and smelling.

items.question: The following are strategies for teaching the concrete operational child. Which is the exception?

choices.text: Opportunities to manipulate and test objects.
Using familiar examples to explain more complex ideas.
Opportunities to classify and group objects and ideas on increasingly complex level
Opportunities to solve problems and reason scientifically.

items.question:
The following conversation occurs between three-year olds
      Cindy: My mommy and daddy and I went to the park.
      Alberto: I got a new toy.
      Cindy: We went on the swings and the seesaw.
      Alberto: I’m going to play with my new toy.
      This conversation exemplifies
Vygotsky and Piaget differed in their views about the relationship of
Vygotsky believed that language learning resulted from

choices.text: Students’ imitating the adults in their environment
Student’s attempts to make sense of their environment
Repetition and reinforcement of adult ideas

items.question: The difference between elementary and higher mental functions in Vygotsky’s theory is that

choices.text: Elementary mental functions are involuntary while higher mental functions involves use of our own will
Elementary mental functions do not involve the use of symbolic thought, while higher mental functions do
Elementary mental functions have no logic to them while higher mental functions involve logical mental operations
Elementary mental functions are due to imitation while higher mental functions require thought

items.question: According to Vygotsky's theory, the zone of proximal development is the area between

choices.text: An individual's performance on an achievement test and his performance on an intelligence test
The level at which an individual can function independently and the level at which the individual can function with assistance
An individual's actual performance and his expected performance
The child's performance on preoperational tasks and his performance on concrete operational tasks

items.question: Cooperative learning will be most likely used by
Vygotsky believed that language was particularly important in children's development because

choices.text: Children use language as a tool to mediate between a task and himself or herself, the performer of the task
It demonstrated that children had achieved higher cognitive stages, such as concrete and formal operations
Children can engage in elementary mental functions through the use of language
Many aspects of language are universal

items.question: Vygotsky would strongly agree to which the following?

choices.text: Margaret got a perfect score in the test. The teacher posts her name on the bulletin board.

When the pupils are beginning a new task, the teacher provides models, coaching and feedback.As the pupils grow in competence, the teacher give less support and more opportunities for independent work.
The teacher assigned in the hinterland observed that children do not know proper hygiene, She taught them hygiene by exhibiting the behavior herself.
The teacher taught the pupils to set reasonable goals and allow them to keep track of their progress.

items.question: Which is essential in the cognitive development of persons according to Vygotsky?

Teacher Felipe believes that teaching involves providing support to his students through prompts, explanations, and questions, and gradually removing those supports until the student is solving problems independently. Teacher Felipe believes in the practice of
A significant difference between the theories of Piaget and Vigotsky is that

choices.text: Piaget was only interested only in development, while Vygotsky was interested only in learning
Piaget places greater emphasis in maturation and experience, while Vygotsky emphasized the role of society
Piaget provided greater insight on the role of the teacher than did Vygotsky
Piaget argued that children use language to regulate themselves, while Vygotsky viewed children's self-talk as a form of egocentric behavior

items.question: For many people, the most productive years according to Erikson are

According to Erikson's theory in which is the individual in if he learns to create or nurture things that will outlast them, often by having children or creating a postive change that benefits other people. Success leads to feelings of usefulness and accomplishment, while failure results in shallow involvement of the world.

John is an average young man who seems to be experimenting with different roles. At home, he is obedient and quiet but with his friends he is relaxed and easily suggests trying out new things. According to Erikson, what stage of development is John experiencing?
If you are a secondary school teacher, which of the following will you do support identity formation?

choices.text: Give students many models for career choices and other adult roles.
Have costumes and props that go along with stories the children enjoy.
Delegate to students such tasks as collecting and distributing materials, watering class plants and keeping records.
Keep samples of earlier work so students can see their improvements.

items.question: When the individual is said to be in the integrity rather than despair stage, what does this mean?

choices.text: He/she is sure of his/her own identity
The individual is able to work positively and creatively
Satisfied with his status among his/her peers in work skills
Developed a self-concept that he can accept and is pleased with his/ her role in life and what he produces.

items.question: Mr. Revalle is a garde 6 adviser. How can he promote moral development in his classroom?

choices.text: Accept misbehavior/ wrong doings of pupils because they are still immature
Disregard the powerful influence as a role model as he interacts with the students
Discourage discussions of topics like honesty and respect for to others in the classroom
Emphasize individual responsibility and the practical nature of rules designed to protect the rights of others

items.question: Which can effectively measure student's awareness of values?
Children's ability to make judgments about moral issues is related to their
What stage of moral development is illustrated by interpreting fairness, reciprocity, and equal sharing in a physical, pragmatic way such as in you scratch my back and I scratch yours?
BJ, a first year high school student, noticed that during their final examination, many of his classmates cheated. In what stage of Kohlberg's theory was BJ's action?

Katrina comes to school on time because it is one of the school's rules and regulation. Besides, she does not like to disrupt their class by coming late. In this situation, which level of Kohlberg's morality does Katrina belong?
The concept of right and wrong as defined by the conscience and self-chosen principles occurs during the _____
Which is the ideal stage of moral development?
Ramil helps his classmate carry heavy books if their teacher sees him and so praise him. In which level of moral development according to Kohlberg Ramil is?
According to Kohlberg, a person's moral development is due to maturational factors and cognitive growth. Which of the following statements best supports his claim?

choices.text: The older the person is, the higher is the level of morality
As the person develops, his morality becomes conventional
As the person grows, his moral reasoning also gets defined
The younger the person is, the higher is his level of morality

items.question: At the high school level, Kohlberg's advice to teachers is for them to begin discussing with students about abstract principles such as justice and human rights. On the average,on which moral development stage are high school students supposed to be?

choices.text: in between conventional and post conventional stage
That depends on the school culture

items.question: There is a distinction between true learning and false learning. Which may be an indication of false learning?

choices.text: Acquisition of knowledge and skills in response to need
Memorizing part of a poem much appreciated
Acquisition of facts for the purpose of getting high marks
Acquisition of attitudes that will change one's way of growth

items.question: What theory of learning involves thinking about learning?
Which of the following changes is an indication of learning?

choices.text: Associating the green light with crossing the street
Feeling drowsy after taking a drug

items.question: All of these are outcomes of learning except:
If a teacher believes that a child's mind is Tabula Rasa, then the teacher will most likely engage the students in _____ process for them to learn.

Teacher Isabel asked her students to describe how their families celebrate holidays. Students can discover that families celebrate holidays differently. Which principle in cognitive development governs Teacher Isabel's teaching activity?

choices.text: Social interaction is essential for cognitive development.
Children often think in different ways at different stages.
Cognitive development involves relating new information to prior knowledge.

items.question: One of the basic principles of cognitivists is that students

choices.text: Learn important facts and score them in memory.
Learn the necessary steps that are required for a task.
Construct knowledge from the information they receive.
Learn that different bodies of knowledge require different procedures.

items.question: Which is NOT an application of the cognitive approach to motivation?

choices.text: Begin lesson with challenging questions/conflicting events.
Explain reasons for studying the topic.
Provide clear and prompt feedback on assignments.

items.question:
Social exposure to various cultures expands a child's pool of knowledge. Which statements go/es with this sentence?
       I.     The less experience the child has, the more disciplined he becomes.
      II.     The more experience the child has, the richer his world becomes.
     III.     The more selective parents in the exposure of their child, the more challenged the child becomes.
As young people mature, society expects them to develop competencies and assume social roles in a conventional manner.
In guiding the development of attitudes and values, a teacher should try to _____

choices.text: Shape students attitudes all the time
Simply discuss moral values with students

items.question: The environment, in order to facilitate learning, must be interactive. Which of the following best typifies this kind of environment?

choices.text: The child copies a list of facts concerning fossils on the blackboard
The child goes out and discovers for himself some rocks and fossils
The child summarizes the section on fossils in his science textbook
The child listens to a lecture on fossils given by the teacher

items.question: Ms. Delgado provides her pupils varies activities hat enable them to classify objects according to one variable, rank and order items in logical series and understanding hat amount of mass and liquid do not change even their shape does. These developmental tasks can be expected to be performed by

If we want students to treat each other with courtesy and dignity then we must do the same to them. If we yell at them, they will soon be shouting at each other. This behavior is likely demonstrated by the students because

choices.text: they are afraid of their teacher if they fail to follow
they learn best by observing a model
they are helpless and entirely dependent on adults
they should be taught to decide for themselves

items.question: Which should be the ultimate aim of teaching?

choices.text: Acquire more facts, concepts and attitudes
Develop desirable habits and attitudes among students

items.question: The best way for a teacher to do when the class has become restless and less attentive is _____

choices.text: Give more incentives such as high grades
Talk more nicely with the inattentive ones
Stop the lesson and wait till the class becomes attentive

items.question: The role that the teacher play when he sets desirable learning activites for the individual leaner and takes responsibility of matching available resources with the needs of each learner
Clare, a junior high school student, has been reported by her teacher to be a habitual absentee and consequently a poor achiever in the class. What initial step should the teacher take?

choices.text: Call her parents to a case conference
Recommend her to transfer to another school
Talk with her and encourage her to unload her problems
Report her to the discipline officer for appropriate action

items.question: Mario keeps on standing and moving around the room while the class is going on. Disruptive behavior in the classroom is a problem that all teachers faced with an would want very much to eliminate. If you were Mario's teacher, which of the following would be most appropriate to help Mario?

choices.text: Ask him to do things to make him busy
Call hist attention and ask questions about the lesson
Talk to him privately to know why he keeps on moving
Scold him in front of the class so he will be ashamed of what he does

items.question: For a teacher to grasp clearly the learner's situation, he needs to feel what the learner feels; to see things as he sees it. This role of the teacher is
Most students will cheat if the pressure to perform well is great and the chance of being caught is slim. How can teachers prevent cheating?

choices.text: Being consistent in enforcing policies regarding cheating
Preparing the students for tests, projects and assignments

items.question: Those who support critical thinking as an important skill to acquire believe it _____

choices.text: Is best addressed outside the classroom
Occurs naturally in an educational environment

items.question: Which of the following would help develop the habit of critical thinking among learners?

choices.text: Asking questions from specific to complex
Reading answers to a variety of questions
Asking and answering high level questions
Gather evidence to support the answers

items.question: Benny, a sophomore student is actively involved in various co-curricular activities. Hi attention, however, was called regarding his deteriorating grades in various subjects. If you were his teacher, what should you advise him to do?

choices.text: Prioritize his concerns with focus on academics
Temporarily go on leave from all school organizations
Terminate his membership in all school organizations
Request his teacher to give him special consideration

items.question: Mr. Rodriguez, a classroom teacher, is aware that he is also expected to perform guidance functions. He has been helping his pupils in their personal and academic problems. What must he do if there are cases which he finds difficult to handle?

choices.text: Bring to the attention of the school principal.
Try to solve them. There are practical solutions to every problem.
Refer them to the guidance counselor who has professional competence to handle such cases.

items.question: JB Watson relates that a particular behavior is determined by environmental factors. Which of the following situations can help the students develop a positive attitude towards Mathematics?

choices.text: Tell students that Math is a difficult subject
Give difficult problems to challenge the students
Present lessons from the easiest to the most complex
Have favorable learning atmosphere in the classroom

items.question: Mr. Soro a  very good teacher, once humiliated a naughty boy named Roy. When asked to evaluate Mr. Soro, Roy gave him a very poor rating. What behavior is illustrated?
When a student displays aggressive behavior in the class, what should the teacher do?

choices.text: Send the student out of the classroom
Threaten the student to win the confidence

items.question: A teacher who has "with-it-ness" will

choices.text: Ask the principal to discipline her class

items.question: Which teacher's activity best develops creativity in the child?

choices.text: Promoting security among children trying out new ideas
Requiring conformity to adult standards and perfection
Encouraging the use of mechanical methods of work
Criticizing the child's work when standards are not met

items.question: The practice of promoting pupils on the basis of age rather achievement or ability most likely results in _____

choices.text: A wide range of differences among these pupils in the classroom
A restricted range in personality, interest and attitudes among these pupils in the classroom
The development of a healthy, well-adjusted individual
Establishment of rapport between teacher and pupil

items.question: Paulo, a preschool boy, remembers that letter S looks like a snake; letter O as an orangel T like a cross is learning through
Student misbehavior is viewed by many educators as a result of

choices.text: The failure of schools to meet the needs of the students

items.question: Research on teacher-effectiveness practices has shown that _________

choices.text: Directions should be few and best delivered in a casual manner.
Planning has little impact on student learning.
Questioning strategies are ineffective monitoring techniques.
Teaching procedures on classroom routines early in the school year are essential.

items.question:
Which is/are evidence/s of a conducive learning environment?
       I.      Students make mistakes and ask for assistance
      II.      Students participate fully in the learning process
     III.      Students are encouraged to ask and answer questions
     IV.     Students attempt new approaches
Which program of the Department of Education is an offshoot of the Filipino Bayanihan spirit?
Between pursuing a college course where there is no demand and a vocational course which is highly in demand, the students usually opt for the college course. Which Filipino trait is demonstrated?
What happens to the child when pushed and pressured by parents to perform more than he is capable of?

choices.text: He tends to be more analytical
He attains mental maturity at an early age
He develops the ability to think fast
He fails to show his real intellectual level

items.question: Teachers are reminded to avoid labeling pupils negatively as they may live up to these images. The tendency to manifest these negative labels into actual behavior describes the ________ concept of attitude formation.

On her first week in school, Ms. Gennie observed pupils who come to school as if they just got out of bed. They are also inattentive and seem to be pathetic and uninterested in their studies. The best step the teacher can do is

choices.text: Send the pupils home so that they can change their clothes
Visit the homes of these pupils so that their parents can be informed of the problem
Separate them from the others who are well-clothed, neat and clean
Leave the pupils alone for they are still too young to keep themselves tidy

items.question: Earl appears to have the charisma of a leader. His classmates follow him readily even in mischief. How would you deal with him?

choices.text: Ignore his behavior for this is part of growing up
Punish him when he leads his classmates to mischief
Organize a group activity to be headed by Earl

items.question: Lino is a boy who thinks he is a good-for-nothing person. Evidently, he does his schoolwork poorly and his parents affirmed this at home. How can you effectively change this "Pygmalion Effect"?

choices.text: assign Lino to be the leader during important activities
let Lino do something easy so that he will experience success
assess Lino's strengths and tap them naturally in class
tell Lino's parents that their son needs help in school

items.question: Which one will most likely increase student participation?

choices.text: feelings or emotions are not permitted in the discussion
the group teacher allows quiet members to remain quiet
the teacher models good listening habits
repeat directions over and over until everyone listens

items.question: Which may not help develop attentive listening in the students?

choices.text: Assigning students to give a summary of a lesson
Asking a student to paraphrase  previous student's response
